report_title: Plus-Size Men's Clothing Stores Industry Report
executive_summary: The Plus-Size Men's Clothing Stores industry sells apparel tailored for men with a waist size of over 40 inches or men that are over six feet two inches tall, usually referred to as big and tall men's clothing. As a result, industry demand is partly correlated with trends in the obesity rate. According to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Disease, the percentage of American men that are overweight or obese remains over 70.0%, which has expanded the industry's core market. However, the majority of purchases of plus-size clothing occurs outside of the industry through a variety of more-popular channels, including e-commerce websites, department stores, mass merchandisers and wholesale clubs. Consequently, industry revenue has declined at an annualized rate of 3.6% to $848.9 million over the five years to 2021. In 2021 alone, industry revenue is estimated to rebound 2.8% due to an increase in consumer spending as industry establishments slowly reopen with the necessary precautions to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Various retailers sell big and tall men's clothing. What sets plus-size men's stores apart is their ability to specialize in this niche market. Industry operators primarily carry lines of larger garments for men, as opposed to more-generalized retailers that may cater to both men and women of various sizes.

During the five-year period, retailers are expected to benefit from a decline in operating expenses. The world price of cotton, a primary input for most apparel products, fell at an annualized rate of 0.2% over the five years to 2021 due to record stockpiles and slower economic growth across key markets around the world.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving economic conditions are expected benefit the industry over the five years to 2026. Per capita disposable income growth is expected to accelerate, rising at an annualized rate of 2.1% during the period. This increase in available funds will enable shoppers to splurge on greater volumes of apparel, as well as more designer and brand-name goods that carry a high price tag, boosting industry revenue.

Heightened competition is also expected to discourage new industry operators to enter the industry. As a result, the number of enterprises is expected to decline an annualized 0.6% to reach 864 companies in 2026. As industry operators continue to hire highly skilled employees to differentiate from the competition, industry wages are expected to remain stagnant at $169.1 million.

industry_definition: This industry includes brick-and-mortar retailers that specialize in plus-size men's clothing, which is commonly referred to as big and tall clothing. This category includes apparel that is proportioned specifically for men with a waist size of over 40 inches or a height of six feet two inches tall.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Men under the age of 35 represent a moderate-sized market for the industry. This segment has expanded as a share of total revenue over the five years to 2021, as an increasing number of young people have become overweight or obese. Furthermore, this segment's significant share of revenue is also a result of the fashion-conscious nature of these consumers and the growing rate of plus-size designer offerings.

Men between ages 35 and 54 are expected to generate 45.2% of industry revenue in 2021, representing the largest consumer segment. Consumers in this cohort generally have steady incomes to spend on various clothing and accessories, as they typically have stable jobs with consistent revenue streams. Men in this category are also more sensitive to fashion trends than older demographics, increasing the frequency of clothing purchases from this category.

Men aged 55 and older are expected to generate 33.0% of industry revenue in 2021, making it the second-largest consumer segment. With the majority of this demographic at retirement age, this segment generally has more leisure time to go to plus-size men's clothing stores and, since they are generally less concerned with fashion trends, the increasing number of products offered by this industry that previously did not exist attracts this market segment.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: While most industry players retail a wide range of goods, from suits to casual wear, industry operators exclusively sell plus-size men's clothing.

FAQs.question: Do your company's advertising campaigns target a wide range of consumers?
FAQs.answer: Industry marketing seeks to target plus-size men, rather than a wide range of general consumers.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Due to the niche products that this market sells, the industry is particularly reliant on high-skilled customer service associates.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: While some industry players have responded to online competition by building their own online store, others have struggled in the face of competition.
